title: Thursday, 12th January, 2017

Let's start with the fallers, I guess. Primark.

Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 2,597, down 101 (-3.74%), High: 2,700, Low: 2,580, Volume: 738.31k
11:07 am
PM11:08am

Yeah

PM11:08am

http://www.investe...1701120700059336T/

BE11:08am

LFL's a tad light against consensus, again.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Guidance is unchanged.

PM11:09am

The market is do demanding of AB Foods

BE11:09am

Europe the problem, mostly. Germany and Netherlands both go into reverse.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

(@Flaneur: first, I'd suggest "don't be daft". Second, I'd suggest reading this: http://www.bbc.com...us-canada-38589427 )

BE11:10am

UK slowing, of course, but we know it is. Business it hitting maturity.

BE11:10am

UBS with the blipview.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Primark LC sales were up 12% on a comparable week basis. Store openings are front end weighted this year and overall Primark LFL looks to be 0-1% with the UK around 2%. UK was a further share gain; Europe was held back by cannibalisation.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Sugar profitability is rising strongly with LC revenue growth of 22% driven by stronger sugar prices and Illovo. There will also be a significant currency benefit particularly from the strength of the euro vs sterling.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: ABF still expects "progress" in adjusted operating profit and EPS in FY17.
Specifically, the Primark EBIT margin guidance of -200bp – primarily as a result of currency – is also unchanged, although this looks like a worst-case scenario.

BE11:11am

Liberum with the longer take.

PM11:11am

You do like these UBS Q&As

11:11 am
BE11:11am

I do. They get to the point.

PM11:12am

But go on, Liberum

BE11:13am

There is, let's be honest, very little properly new news in most earnings reports beyond the numbers and the outlook statement. I think it's fair enough to sum them rather than use it as a hook to repeat whatever view you had going into the update.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

However ................ uh, ignore all that. Here's Liberum.

BE11:13am

ABF reported solid 1Q17 trading with constant FX revenues 10% ahead of year-ago (+22% reported). Despite a tough retail environment, Primark sales rose 22% driven by 12% new space growth, flat LfL and favourable FX. EBIT margin remains pressured by adverse FX. Sugar profitability is improving driven by cost savings, lower beet costs and improved pricing coupled with strong production in Africa. In FY’17 we expect a strong rebound in group profits as Sugar profits recover and Primark continues a strong store roll-out program. ABF offers compelling exposure to secular growth trends in retail over the next 5-10 years. We estimate Primark can double sales and profits over the next 5 years. We rate AB Foods BUY with a 3,100p target price.

BE11:13am

Primark delivered 11% revenue growth at constant exchange rates driven by a 12% rise in selling space. Positive FX from weaker £ adds 11% to sales. LfL sales were flat despite weak high street footfall as Primark lapped soft results year ago. The impact of new store opens in Germany and the Netherlands on like-for-like sales continues to fade. New stores opened in the period traded strongly Operating profit margin in the period is in line with expectations and will decline during the course of the fiscal year due to the strong US dollar. Stock levels were well managed and there are FX contracts in place for the remaining stock purchases this year. Primark's US operations are progressing well with a sixth store opened in Burlington, MA. The group’s Continental roll-out continues apace. In total, Primark opened 13 new stores and 2 relocations comprising 0.8m sqf new space in 1Q’07. Total increase in selling space is expected to reach 1.3m in FY’17.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Sales improved in 1Q'17 as the group starts to benefit from rising EU sugar prices and favourable FX rates. Production is improving in Southern Africa which is coming out of a period of sustained drought with production expected to reach 1.7m tons vs 1.4m tons in FY’16. The global sugar market is forecast for another year of production deficits which coupled with a tightening of EU stock levels and higher world prices versus year ago is underpinning stronger prices domestic and regional markets. Profitability is improving strongly as British sugar benefits from cost savings initiatives and lower sugar beet costs and improving EU sugar prices will boost FY’17 as the year progresses. The sugar campaign is well under way with sugar product expected to be below year ago levels due lower planting levels and yields in the UK and stronger production in Africa.

BE11:13am

Twinings Ovaltine delivered solid sales with strength at Twinings in North America, Australia and the UK and in Asia for Ovaltine. Australian grocery trading continues to improve with stronger margins. The UK bakery market remains intensely competitive with over-capacity still in the industry. Allied Bakeries remains strong but pricing and margins remain challenging.

BE11:14am

Agriculture revenues improved across all business units. AB Mauri and Ingredients continued to see healthy improvement in margin.

FY'17 outlook – reiterating guidance for progress in adj. operating profit and earnings

ABF reiterated guidance for progress in adjusted operating profit and adjusted earnings in FY’17.

We rate AB Foods a BUY with a 3,100p target price. ABF offers compelling exposure to secular growth trends in retail over the next 10 years. ABF’s underlying fundamentals appear robust underpinning our conviction that profits will show solid recovery from FY’17. We think the shares can hold their rating as investors look through near-term headwinds towards the long-term. Excluding M&A and further store parcels, we estimate ABF will deliver 10% adjusted EPS CAGR through FY’20E although growth could improve if FX rates improve or Primark’s roll-out quickens.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Did I fail to see Spain mentioned in the Primark update, incidentally?

BE11:15am

It's the group's #2 market.

BE11:16am

Guess it was probably mentioned on the conference call ... which I don't have time to listen to because a zillion bloody trading updates.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Just gets a mention in passing in the statement

PM11:16am

In relation to new store openings

PM11:16am

And that's it

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Hm.

BE11:16am

Jefferies as well ......

BE11:16am

Today's Q1 update has no impact on ST estimates. A flat LFL at Primark masks resilient performance in the UK and pressure in Europe (due to self-cannibalisation). The extent to which Primark can minimise margin pain in the coming months remains a point of debate. Recent currency, cotton, freight rate moves represent incremental challenges. And, given this context, multiples are unlikely to rebuild in the near term.

No changes to estimates post Q1 sales... with ABF confirming 16/17 guidance for progress in both EBIT and EPS (JEFe +14%/+12% with fx at +6%) , aided by the translation benefit of £ devaluation (which in turn should put Primark's gross margin under pressure) and a major rebound in sugar profits.

...but flat Primark LFL lower than hoped for as it compares with JEFe/cons of +2%/+1% and it follows a recovery back to +ve territory in the first few weeks of Q1 (as outlined at the 9 Dec AGM). We believe UK LFL to have been around 2% in the period, which would be resilient for a non multi-channel player. This was offset by self-cannibalisation in Europe (especially in Holland and Germany). The cosmetically unhelpful dynamic is no clear return to quarterly +ve LFL yet (now an absent feature since 14/15).

A number of factors have inflected unhelpfully in recent weeks... Currency hedges are now in place for most of 16/17 (still implying an acceleration in margin decline in H2 due to $ strength). Rebounding cotton prices (now 11% higher vs. 2016 average, in US$) and Asia to Europe freight rates (70% higher than the average for 2016, in US$, but 90% in £) are an industry wide challenge. However, they have a disproportionate impact on Primark's low ASP and gross margin model.

...and valuation remains pretty full. We assume investors are paying around 11x cal 2018 sugar earnings and 16x for other non-Primark earnings (a reduced discount to a sharply derated staples peer group). This leaves Primark priced at 22.4x cal 2018 earnings vs. ABF on 19.5x. This is sharply below the Q4 2015 peaks, but not unduly so given a FC margin reduction from 900bps to 600bps. ABF's understandable (and wise) progressive approach to US expansion is another important consideration for the overall multiples debate.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Valuation: 2450p = SOTP placing Primark's cal 2018E earnings on 20x, sugar on 11x and the balance on c.16x.

BE11:18am

Primark 20x 2018 compares with H&M and Inditex on 22 and 31x 2017, in case you're interested.

PM11:18am

PM11:18am

11:18 am

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 339.60, down 0.8 (-0.24%), High: 359.80, Low: 338.00, Volume: 13.54m
11:18 am
PM11:19am

Well, it's un-budged live

BE11:19am

Better against extremely low expectations, and it's at the start of yet another restructuring programme.

BE11:19am

A programme it'll have to do while inflation moves higher

11:20 am
BE11:20am

The solution remains for M&S to partially spin off its Simply Food business at a Whole Foods multiple and spend the proceeds on some softer lightbulbs for its stores, but we've hammered that point quite often.

BE11:21am

Here's Investec to summarise.

BE11:21am

While Clothing & Home sales were better than expected with LFLs +2.3%, this was helped by a 1.5% calendar effect and more normalised weather. It is too early to call a victory and with a slowdown in consumer spending expected in the year ahead, we believe this could well go negative again. M&S is playing catch up from a difficult mid-market clothing position and with little medium-term visibility over profits or cash generation and negative TSR dynamics, we expect the shares to continue to underperform. We reiterate our Sell.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Q3 Clothing & Home better than consensus – Reported (13 weeks to 31 Dec) LFL +2.3% (INVe Q3 +1%; Bloomberg consensus flat; Q2 –2.9%), helped by more seasonal weather and 5 days extra trading in Q3 as the quarter-end shifted from 26th Dec last year. This added 1.5% to C&H and will reverse in Q4, causing a c.2.5% impact as Q4 is a smaller quarter. Online sales +9.4% (Q2 +0.4%; Q1 +0.2%). Full price sales up 13% with promotions substantially reduced in the period, particularly over Black Friday, and lower stock into sale down 7%.
Q3 Food in line with LFL 0.6% (INVe Q3 +1%; cons -0.5%; Q2 -0.9%) with calendar effect adding c.0.3%. No Easter in Q4 expected to impact by 1-1.5%.
No changes to forecasts with FY guidance reiterated – C&H gross margin 0 to +50bps (INVe +40bps) including (1) 120bps FX headwind; (2) Food gross margin flat (INVe flat); and ( 3) Opex +3.5% (INVe +3.2%).
Retain Sell – M&S has just started a 5-year restructuring strategy, which we estimate could deliver 25% incremental EBIT, but this will be back-end weighted (FY21/22) and there is execution risk. We remain of the view that Mr Rowe’s strategy is likely to end up being no more than a ‘steady the ship’ strategy, with little medium-term visibility over profits or cash generation. M&S is playing catch up from a difficult mid-market clothing position in a market we expect to slow in 2017. Given the low probability of cash returns over the medium term, the change in M&S’ future growth prospects, limited forecast visibility and negative TSR dynamics, we see further downside potential. Valuation not cheap enough for the risk.

PM11:21am

Tony Shiret's a reluctant buyer

PM11:21am

Haitong

11:21 am
PM11:22am

Is there anything in these results or the accompanying commentary that provides insight into the new trading strategy and its resonance and sustainability with consumers? We believe that the stock into sale decline of 7% yoy and general absence of promotional activity in the face of a heavily promotional pre-Christmas market alongside the sales achievement were together positive in the context of delivering a better, more full price strategy in C&H. We felt very uncertain going into these results given the extent of the change in strategy in a difficult market. The resumption of growth in online +9.4% again without the benefit of much promotion was a positive.

PM11:22am

here is in our view a lowish degree of visibility on the phasing of plans regarding the reshaping of the UK estate, which makes for a degree of uncertainty re medium term forecasting. 2017/18 should see the elimination of part of £45m losses on the soon to be closed part of the international estate. But the more general repositioning of the UK Home & Clothing range has had limited results and how M&S’s price and desirability repositioning in Women’s wear plays out in a soon to be inherently inflationary market (FX) is hard to predict.

Theoretically we should be able to project some kind of end-result from the repositioning and discount back (in the style of Kingfisher (KGF LN, 344p, Sell, FV 170p). But that would require a lot more information than we currently have.

PM11:22am

We have been positive on M&S on largely tactical grounds, seeing CEO Steve Rowe’s strengths as execution based, allowing profit stabilisation and recovery against weak comparatives. At this stage we do not really believe that M&S will get to a point where it is capable of long term sales-based growth given its starting point and the relatively undynamic nature of what has been proposed so far in the UK. But we believe that today is a good day for Mr Rowe and the company. Obviously it makes the recent Next (NXT LN, 4137p, Buy, FV 4800p) Christmas trade showing look quite poor.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Bernstein too, since we're covering the bases.

BE11:22am

We expect M&S shares to be up today on the better than expected LFL sales growth in Clothing & Home, particularly given the category backdrop and Next’s comments from last week. While some of this strong performance was due to timing (the inclusion of the week after Christmas is this year’s Q3 number) and will reverse in Q4, we expect investors will be encouraged by management’s positive tone and continued commitment to reduce promotional levels. With respect to numbers, sales expectations will likely come up for the year, despite the anticipated timing reversal in Q4 but so too will cost expectations. This is an area where M&S has historically beaten expectations given weaker sales, but with better sales will be higher cost growth. Overall we expect consensus to be largely unchanged. We rate M&S underperform (TP: GBp 285).

BE11:23am

And Exane's summary off the call.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Whilst management opened with cautious comments on calendar benefits reversing and an ongoing tough environment, the remainder of the call was filled with positive commentary. Citing merchandising, pricing, staffing and other proposition investments, management spoke to good traction on Clothing and Home core ranges and improved full-price sales. Further work is to be done, but management are confident the changes being made are in the right direction and having an impact. The positive trends were exactly in line with management expectations, across both Clothing and Food, with margins within both also as expected. As a result guidance remains unchanged, but does look well underpinned to ourselves. Together, there is little to fault in today’s update, although we would caution that the combination of calendar and comparatives is flattering an underlying trend that will return across cal-2018.

undefined
PM11:23am

Now Im bored with retail

11:23 am

And we havent even done AO World

PM11:24am

Or Debs for that matter

PM11:24am

Drugs!

11:23 am
PM11:24am

PM11:24am

Shire has been for sure

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 4,526, down 155.8 (-3.33%), High: 4,609, Low: 4,500, Volume: 1.32m
11:24 am
PM11:24am

Knee-jerk reaction?

BE11:24am

Hm. Well, yes. Probably.

BE11:25am

The issue with Trump ......... sorry, I should say one issue with Trump, because they're myriad ..... is that there's a disconnect between when you listen to him and when you read what he's said.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

It's a Barnum trick. Here's the transcript of his stuff about drug companies.

BE11:26am

We’ve got to get our drug industry back. Our drug industry has been disastrous. They’re leaving left and right. They supply our drugs, but they don’t make them here, to a large extent. And the other thing we have to do is create new bidding procedures for the drug industry because they’re getting away with murder.

Pharma, pharma has a lot of lobbies and a lot of lobbyists and a lot of power and there’s very little bidding on drugs. We’re the largest buyer of drugs in the world and yet we don’t bid properly and we’re going to start bidding and we’re going to save billions of dollars over a period of time.

BE11:26am

So ........... This is ...... Unclear, I guess, would be a polite way to put it? And the sense we can pick out of it doesn't look awfully new.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

So what, he's talking about the way insurers pay for drugs?

PM11:27am

with this bidding process?

BE11:27am

Kinda. But this is complicated, and has been in various states of non-reform for four decades.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Note that Trump repeatedly proposed direct Medicare price negotiation while on the hustings.

BE11:28am

He's also talked already about price transparency, and the onshoring of overseas drugs (however the hell that might work)

BE11:28am

There's a good backgrounder here: http://healthaffai...price-negotiation/

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Useful

BE11:29am

The people who are paid to turn Trump's utterances into some kind of sense are translating this into Medicare Part D reform, which is currently the hole in Medicare's doughnut.

BE11:29am

Part D prices -- which are for oncology, of course, but also stuff like depression treatments and antipsychotics -- are about a third higher when adjusted for mix.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

(Was just reading that Health Affairs blog you linked to -- it really does make the head spin.)

BE11:31am

(I like healthcare regulation specifically because it makes your head spin. It's where politics meets capitalism, often resulting in dead people.)

BE11:32am

Anyway, for Shire I think its dry-eye treatment thingmy is up for Part D classification next year.

11:00 am
PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:34am

Which is my way of saying, "sorry, I don't have any new sellside to share right now. See the archive."

undefined
11:34 am
BE11:35am

From Shire to Spire, then.

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 313.93, down 31.17 (-9.03%), High: 337.20, Low: 308.00, Volume: 1.09m
BE11:35am

Okay statement .... apart from St Anthony's

11:35 am
PM11:36am

http://www.investe...1701120700109875T/

BE11:36am

A hospital in North Cheam it bought in 2014

PM11:36am

https://en.wikiped...g/wiki/St._Anthony's_Hospital,_North_Cheam

11:36 am
BE11:36am

That's the one. Here are some people laughing while walking through a wood.

BE11:36am

https://www.spireh...anthonys-hospital/

BE11:37am

Ignoring St Anthony's, Spire's in line. Including it, it's a 2017 profit warning.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Here's Numis.

BE11:38am

Spire Healthcare has announced a disappointing update highlighting the redevelopment and reconfiguration of St Anthony’s hospital that is taking longer than anticipated, which together with the final NHS Tariff for 2017/2018 is expected to weigh on FY17 performance. FY16 revenues are expected to be c.£925m and in line (NSe £923.5m, Factset cons £926.6m) with EBITDA of c.£162m, 2.6% lighter than our expectations (NSe £166.4m, Cons £167.5m). For FY17E; EBITDA is expected to be ‘in line with 2016’, which is against our estimate of £178.8m and Cons at £174.8m, and therefore is 7-9% lower than ours and market expectations, and we place our forecasts under review. Spire notes that while the 6 theatre development at St Anthony’s was completed on time in H2 2016, ‘work to reconfigure staffing levels, clinical processes and competencies to take full advantage of this additional capacity is still ongoing and is not now expected to be completed until H2 2017’. Further, the NHS tariff is expected to be an average -3.9% reduction from April 2017, which is ahead of Spire's original expectations at H1 results of ‘marginally greater’ than the -2.5% average expected for the independent sector (as outlined by NHS improvement). As a reminder, Spire generates c.70% of group revenues from private payors (PMI and Self-Pay) and c.30% from NHS patients (of which 70% are orthopaedic revenues). Cashflow has ‘remained strong’ and net debt leverage is expected to be c.2.7x EBITDA at the end of 2016. The new hospital openings of Manchester and Nottingham are on track – opening Jan ’17 and April ’17 respectively (previously both anticipated in Q1). Spire also expects the group to return to ‘mid to high single digit EBITDA growth from FY2018 onwards’. While a tougher NHS Tariff environment was anticipated, the performance at St Anthony’s hospital is unexpected. However, we continue to believe that Spire remains in a strong position to benefit from an NHS under pressure by offering a private alternative as well as taking on additional public volumes where capacity allows - and note continued recent strong growth in NHS e-referral volumes.

BE11:39am

And Liberum.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

2016 EBITDA miss driven by St Anthony's, underlying business performing well

Spire delivered revenues of £925m which was up 4.5% reported and at the top end of its 3-5% guidance range. Despite this, EBITDA of £162m was 3% short of consensus estimates with the 17.5% margin well below the 18.0% management had guided to. This was driven entirely by issues at Spire St Anthony's, a hospital it acquired in 2014 and has significantly expanded since. The hospital generated an EBITDA loss of £1.5m versus a profit of £5m the previous year. Excluding this effect, Spire would have delivered revenue growth of 4.9% and an EBITDA margin of 18.3%, well ahead of guidance.

While management provided little detail on the issues at St Anthony's we believe the site expansion (building of new operating theatres) combined with a restructuring of operations since acquisition are likely to have led to cost issues. We expect these to persist into H1 2017 although the company should be able to turn this around by the second half.

2017 guidance to drive near-term downgrades

While the underlying business generated EBITDA growth of 5.5% in 2016 despite some headwinds and there are a number of tailwinds in 2017, we believe the issues at St Anthony's will weigh on earnings next year. This has been reflected in guidance with management expecting EBITDA to be flat for 2017 before returning to mid-to-high single digit growth from 2018. Consensus currently expects 2017 EBITDA of £175m implying a downgrade of 6-7% at the EBITDA level, although net income forecasts are likely to fall by a little more. Given the issues are cost and not revenue driven, Spire may be able to make a lot of this up in 2018 if it can turn St Anthony's around and therefore the longer-term downgrades may be less substantial.

NHS tariff largely as expected, provides good visibility

The NHS tariff for 2017/18 (effective April 2017-March 2018) and 2018/19 (effective April 2018-March 2019) was finalised on December 22 last year. Spire management has analysed this two year tariff and believes that assuming procedure mix remains constant, its NHS price will fall by an average of 3.9% in 2017/18 and be flat in 2018/19. If the tariff is "calendarised" for Spire's fiscal year then we estimate an impact of -2.6% for 2017 and -1.0% for 2019. This is more or less as we had expected (albeit with different phasing). We think this is quite a good result for Spire and more importantly gives it price visibility for two years, something it has never had before. Importantly, with two year's visibility, Spire will be better able to shift its procedure mix toward higher value services and therefore the ultimate price impact may be meaningfully better than expected.

Disappointing update with one difficult hospital overshadowing a strong performance across the rest of the portfolio

Today's update will dent investor confidence in management as following a challenging 2015, Spire had begun to demonstrate that the business was back on-track to deliver growth. That said, with the underlying business performing ahead of expectations, we believe there is still the potential for Spire to deliver strong growth in the mid-term once it can resolve the issues at St Anthony's. We would expect the shares to come under pressure today.

BE11:40am

Haven't heard the Mediclinic - Spire rumour for a few months, incidentally.

BE11:41am

Last time it came up, which was September, the Feltcollaredsource were very dismissive of the idea.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Said it was just JP Morgan causing trouble, and that Mediclinic was in no state to do anything after a profit warning.

PM11:42am

Fair enough

BE11:43am

Yup. And that preceded another several profit warnings. One assumes something will happen here eventually, but I don't get the feeling that Mediclinic desperately wants the UK healthcare system to add to the multiple fires it's already putting out.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

(Disclaimer: not literal fires.)

PM11:43am

Oh look at this

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Launch of First Chinese A-Share ETF on LSE

PM11:43am

What could possibly go wrong?

PM11:43am

London, January 12th 2017: GF International Asset Management (UK) ("GF International"), the European division of GF Fund Management, the Chinese fund management company, has today announced the launch of its first fund product, the GF International-FTSE China A UCITS ETF. The ETF (exchange-traded fund) is listed today on the London Stock Exchange.

11:43 am
PM11:44am

As of October 31st 2016 the index included 779 company shares traded on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets. It is the first ETF to use the FTSE China A Index, which is the sub-index most likely to be included in the broad-based FTSE Emerging Market Index when the expected Chinese market inclusion decision is made.

PM11:44am

Who are GF International?

PM11:44am

Ok, seems well established

11:44 am
PM11:44am

GF International Asset Management UK ("GF International") is the European subsidiary of GF Fund Management ("GF FM") in China, and the first wholly Chinese-owned asset manager established in Europe.

GF Fund Management has managed mutual funds in China since 2003. GFFM's total assets under management were over RMB 485 billion (USD 70.1 billion) by December 2016. GF Fund Management has been consistently ranked as one of the largest fund managers in China since 2006. It offers a diverse range of over 200 investment products to Chinese investors, spanning equities, fixed income and alternative assets, supported by a team of over 100 investment professionals.

BE11:45am

How on earth does the issuer run a China ETF given many, if not most, of its stocks spend much of their time suspended limit up and down?

BE11:45am

Not my problem, I guess.

11:45 am
PM11:45am

http://www.gffunds.com.hk/en/

PM11:45am

Just keep an eye on that

BE11:46am

I'm sure the employees of the The Scotsman and The Yorkshire Post will be thrilled with this.

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 714.50, down 35 (-4.67%), High: 739.00, Low: 708.50, Volume: 1.43m
BE11:54am

Citi negative.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Revising estimates to adjust mix of growth and increase 2017E opex
We are revising our forecasts for Inmarsat to reduce the rate of revenue growth that we expect in Maritime, partly compensated by Government, and to allow a heavier yoy rise in opex in 2017 in Aviation and Central Services for commercialisation of GlobalXpress (GX) and EAN. The net is a fall in our forecasts for EBITDA excl the Ligado lease of c.8% in 2017 and 9% in 2018, with no change in 2016. Taking into account the resulting lower FCF profile and a slightly higher WACC, our target price falls to £8.00 (from £9.80) and we return our rating to Neutral from Buy.

BE11:54am

Investing to grow but growth needs demonstrating
We believe that Inmarsat is right to be investing heavily to target fast-growing demand for broadband connectivity in the maritime and aviation markets. It saw a number of positive developments during 2016 including: (1) signing for GlobalXpress by three major Maritime resellers: Marlink (for over 2,000 vessels), Speedcast (c.2,000) and Navarino (over 1,200), (2) confirmation of the key support contract under the US Navy’s Commercial Broadband Satellite Program, and (3) confirmation from IAG and Air New Zealand that they will be deploying GX and/or European Aviation Network (EAN) services along with expanding commitments from Lufthansa affiliates. Both the Clarksea and Baltic Dry indices have also recovered from their summer lows, suggesting that the worst may be over for the maritime market.

BE11:54am

Revenue needs to follow to demonstrate financial value
From here we expect to see the contract momentum continuing to build and turning into increased revenue and greater confidence over the outlook. The sector is noisy with overhang of capacity in certain regions and uncertainty around the longer-term outlook for yields, despite recognition that demand is likely to grow strongly as terminals deploy. We now expect ex-Ligado EBITDA to fall yoy in 2017 to $624m – total EBITDA $735m – with revenue up but costs set to rise more as the company steps up its commercial efforts. Revenue visibility remains hazy, however, and we expect the company to fall well short of its 2018 target range ($1.45-1.60bn ex Ligado).

BE11:58am

Small beat to consensus, confident guidance for 2017

This trading update will be a relief to the market, in our view, given the negative research published in December by Spotlight Research. However, the stock has performed well with the stock returning 30% since its recent lows. The stock still trades at a material discount to its peer group with continued concerns about the Asia Gateway exposure. We estimate that Asia Gateway is c. 20% of earnings. If we were to exclude the Asia Gateway business the stock would trade at 12.7x 2017E earnings, still a material discount considering our forecast of double-digit growth.

Details of trading update

Paysafe announced its trading update for full year 2016. Revenues should exceed $1bn (guidance $970-990m, consensus $988m) and EBITDA c$300m (guidance 287-293m, cons 292m). This assumes margins close to 30% (implied guidance of 29.6%) as expected.

Paysafe provided preliminary guidance for FY17E of low double digit revenue growth and at least maintaining EBITDA margins. This implies revenue of c. $1.12bn (c 3% higher than current consensus). Cash conversion is stated as being strong which we interpret as cash flow being in-line with expectations.

Valuation

The stock trades on 7.9x 2017E earnings and 7.9x EBITDA. Our price target assumes a P/E of 13.5x and 10x EBITDA.

BE12:00pm

.... Oh, and there's the Ogden rate.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Which had its first ever mention in the FT two days ago: https://www.ft.com...-944b-e7eb37a6aa8e

BE12:02pm

And will now get its second. Basically, this is is the discount rate insurers have to use to calculate payouts for injury claims when the victim takes the lump-sum option.

BE12:02pm

Very small changes cause very big effects to total costs, and there's a change coming at the end of the month (probably).

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Andy Hughes at Macquarie kicks the issue around this morning.

BE12:03pm

On 31st January 2017, the Lord Chancellor is expected to announce a new Ogden discount rate, used to calculate compensation in large bodily injury claims. Although the current rate is 2.5%, we understand that most insurers currently carry a margin, covering the cost of a 100bps reduction to 1.5%.

However, we expect the Lord Chancellor to set the rate between 1% and 1.5%. Thus if the rate falls to below 1.5%, then reserves across the industry could require strengthening. We expect that this could cost £90m each for Admiral and Direct Line, in excess of the reserve margin we expect they currently hold.

Lower future earnings as margin in reserves is used

Moreover, use of this margin in large bodily injury reserves will mean reduced reserve releases in the future, with a negative impact on earnings from 2017.

This is partially offset by falling PPO propensity (lump sums will be more attractive with a lower Ogden rate than Periodic Payment Orders), which will result in minor reserve releases.

BE12:03pm

Admiral and Direct Line most impacted

With a higher proportion of young drivers (meaning more large claims) and less excess of loss reinsurance, we find that Admiral is one of the most exposed UK motor insurers. Our earnings forecasts for Admiral are 12% below consensus in 2017 and 20% below in 2018.

We also find that Direct Line is highly exposed to this change, primarily through high reserves in older accident years. As Direct Line sources 70% of its operating profits from reserve releases, its earnings could be especially adversely affected by lower releases in future years. Our earnings forecasts for Direct Line are 16% below consensus in 2017 and 26% below in 2018.

Downgrade Direct Line to underperform

Given that the upcoming decision could result in material one-off reserve strengthening and reduced reserve releases going forward, we expect that Admiral and Direct Line will continue to underperform.

As such we reiterate our Underperform recommendation for Admiral and target price of 1542p. We also downgrade Direct Line to Underperform (from Neutral) with a new target price of 295p (down from 345p).
